title: Pear Tallow Balm: The Weird Stuff That Actually Fixed My Winter Skin
body:
Look. My hands were a disaster. Like, a real situation. This was back in, I don't know, early December maybe. I was using that O’Keeffe’s Working Hands stuff in the green tub. You know the one. Everyone says it’s the best. My dad swears by it. And my skin just… ate it. It would feel okay for like twenty minutes, and then it was like I’d put nothing on at all. My knuckles were these red, cracked maps. Washing dishes felt like a punishment. I’d stare at my hands and just think, *well this is pathetic*. I’m 34. I shouldn’t have hands that look like I’ve been fist-fighting sandpaper.

So I was scrolling Etsy one night, half-watching some true crime thing, and I kept seeing this tallow balm stuff. Beef tallow. For your skin. My first thought was, obviously, *what the actual hell*. That’s for candles. Or cooking. Not for putting on your face. But the algorithm had me, and I kept seeing this one shop with a whipped tallow balm in a pear scent. The pictures looked nice. Simple. And I was desperate. My regular store products weren’t cutting it. This whole natural vs commercial skincare debate wasn’t even on my radar—I just wanted my hands to not hurt.

I clicked. The description said it was whipped beef tallow from grass-fed cows, made in France. Said it was similar to our skin’s own oils, so it sinks in deep. For rough hands, winter damage, all that. I figured, worst case, I’m out thirty bucks and I have a very fancy candle ingredient. So I ordered the pear one. Subtle sweetness, it said. Light and fresh.

It showed up on a Tuesday. The cat was judging me hardcore from the couch.

## What This Beef Tallow Stuff Actually Is

Okay so it arrives. Small jar. Cute label. I open it. The texture was… weird. Not bad weird. It’s like this super dense, kind of waxy cream? But then you touch it and it just melts. It doesn’t feel greasy like Vaseline or that slimy silicone feel some lotions have. It’s hard to explain. It’s solid in the jar but the second it hits your skin, it’s gone. Vanishes.

The smell. Right. Pear tallow balm. I was braced for something funky, because, you know, beef fat. But it didn’t smell like beef at all. Smelled like… a pear? But not a candy pear. Not like a Jolly Rancher. More like if you had a really ripe pear sitting in a cool room. A clean, fruity smell. Gentle. Not perfume-y. It was just nice. Simple. I put a tiny bit on the back of my hand just to test.

It absorbed. Like, actually absorbed. Didn’t sit on top of my skin making everything I touched slippery. My skin just drank it. It felt… calm. That’s the only word. Not “moisturized” in that plastic-wrap way lotions sometimes feel. Just calm. And soft. But a different soft. My own skin soft, not lotion-coated soft.

I started using it that night. Just on my hands. My poor, cracked, O’Keeffe’s-forsaken hands.

## How This Weird Balm Beat My Fancy Lotions

Here’s the thing about commercial moisturizers. I’ve tried a bunch. That Neutrogena Norwegian Formula hand cream? Sticky. The Gold Bond Ultimate Healing? Smelled like a hospital and pills. CeraVe in the tub? Fine, I guess, but it never felt like it did anything lasting. They all seem to work on the surface. They put a temporary layer on top of the problem. This tallow balm felt like it was fixing the problem from underneath. If that makes any sense. Probably doesn’t.

I got mine from this little Etsy shop, by the way. Just a person making it. Felt less weird buying it from there than from some big company, you know?

After about three days, I noticed the cracks on my knuckles weren’t bright red anymore. They were just… there. Not angry. A week in, they started to actually close up. I’d wake up and my hands didn’t feel tight and stiff. I could make a fist without wincing. It was wild. I didn’t expect much but honestly, it worked. It just worked.

So then I got brave. Or stupid. One of those. My face gets dry and flaky in winter too, especially around my nose and forehead. I’ve used that La Roche-Posay Toleriane moisturizer that costs like forty dollars. It’s fine. Does the job. But I thought, what the hell. Let’s try the tallow. I was scared it would clog my pores. I have that skin that’s dry but also gets random bumps if I use something too heavy.

I used a tiny, tiny amount. Like half a pea. Warmed it between my fingers and just patted it on my dry spots before bed.

No clogged pores. No breakouts. My skin just looked… even. Hydrated. Not shiny. Not greasy. Just normal. Like how skin is supposed to look. I started using it every night. My fancy forty-dollar moisturizer is just sitting in the cabinet now. I feel a little bad for it. But not that bad.

## My Skin Now vs. Then (And a Random Tangent)

It’s been a few weeks. Maybe a month? I don’t keep track. My hands are normal. Actually normal. I can wash them without immediately needing to slather on cream. The skin on my face doesn’t flake under makeup anymore. My elbows, which were always rough and kinda ashy, are smooth. I don’t know when that happened. I just noticed it one day.

It’s not a miracle. It doesn’t make you look ten years younger or whatever. It just makes your skin behave like skin. It fixes the winter damage. The rough patches. The psoriasis on my dad’s elbows—I got him a jar for Christmas and he grumbled about it being “hippie stuff” but he texted me last week saying it’s the only thing that’s helped. So there’s that.

Anyway my coffee is getting cold. I’m typing this with one hand.

The point is, I switched from my regular store products to this tallow balm and the difference is… real. It’s not a subtle “maybe it’s working” thing. It’s a “oh, my skin isn’t a problem anymore” thing. I’m on my second jar now. I keep one by my bed and one in my bag. It’s my best natural moisturizer, hands down. No contest.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, weirdly, it is. From what I read, it’s similar to the oils our skin makes naturally. So it doesn’t just sit on top—it gets absorbed and helps your skin do its own thing. My face loves it. No breakouts, just happy skin.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Not in my experience. And I was worried about that too. It absorbs really well, so it doesn’t just block everything up. It’s not like slathering on coconut oil or something. It sinks in and disappears.

**What does the pear tallow balm smell like?**
It’s nice. A clean, light pear smell. Not artificial. Not overpowering. Just a gentle, fresh scent that fades pretty quick after you put it on. It’s not like walking around smelling like a fruit salad.

So yeah. If your skin is being difficult with regular lotions, especially in the winter, this tallow balm might be worth a shot. I was super skeptical but now I’m just… not. It just works. I don’t know what else to say. My skin’s happy, I’m happy. That’s the whole review.
